Burntisland from the top of The Binn

Burntisland is on the "Fife Circle" train line from
. Trains from Edinburgh take 35 minutes, and there are often 2 per hour.
The main sites can be explored on foot.

value: All Our Yesterdays - Life Before the Mobile
. An exhibition of town history is held in the Burgh Chambers on the High Street on Wed-Sun in summer. Also a good place to ask for general tourist information.
opened in 1594 and has an interesting painted interior (open summer Saturdays). It was the first church to be built in Scotland after the Reformation.

Go to the Fair in Summer on The Links.
Go for a swim at the Beacon Leisure Centre
Excellent fish and chips are to be had at Romanos on the High Street.
There's decent basic food at the Ramblers Rest deli.

The town is well serviced by hotels and bars catering to all tastes commensurate with the standing of a Fife coastal town.
